Situation1: They review project timelines casually, ensuring tasks are generally progressing.
Expectation2: Advocate for policy changes by contacting legislators and participating in lobbying efforts.
Situation2: A key legislative aide has just called and has ten minutes to talk right now about the bill you are campaigning for.
Story: I was sitting at my desk, blueprints spread out before me, half-listening to my project manager update me on the latest construction delays. As the lead architect, I was expected to keep everything running smoothly, but I’d gotten used to reviewing timelines with a casual eye, trusting my team to handle the details. My phone buzzed, and I glanced at the screen—an unknown number. I almost ignored it, but something made me answer. It was a legislative aide, the one I’d been trying to reach for weeks about the green building bill. She said she had ten minutes to talk, right now. My heart pounded. This was the moment I’d been waiting for as an activist, the chance to push for real change. But my project manager was still talking, waiting for my input on a critical decision. I could see the expectation in her eyes: be present, be efficient, keep the project on track. I felt torn, the weight of both roles pressing down on me, knowing I couldn’t give my full attention to both at once.
